title: A Phase 1, Randomized, Open-Label, Single Dose Cross-Over Study In Healthy Volunteers To Estimate The Pharmacokinetics Of Four Modified-Release Formulations Of Dimebon (Latrepirdine)
description_brief: This study will evaluate four different modified release formulation to estimate the amount of dimebon available to the body relative to the current dimebon formulation that is given three times a day. The results of this study will help inform and guide further formulation development efforts with the ultimate goal of reducing dose frequency to once-a-day or twice-a-day.
explanation_target: Reason: The trial is a Phase 1 pharmacokinetic/formulation study of modified‑release formulations of dimebon (latrepirdine) in healthy volunteers to change dosing frequency; it is not an efficacy trial. The intervention is an oral small‑molecule drug rather than a biologic.

Act: Latrepirdine (Dimebon) is an orally active small‑molecule originally developed as an antihistamine and later investigated as a potential cognition‑enhancing/neuroprotective agent for Alzheimer’s disease (multiple mechanisms proposed, not a monoclonal antibody or anti‑amyloid biologic). citeturn0search12turn0search3

Reflect: Given the drug class (small molecule) and its investigational use as a putative cognition enhancer in Alzheimer’s trials (rather than a biologic targeting amyloid/tau or a therapy primarily for neuropsychiatric symptoms), the most appropriate category is "cognitive enhancer." Note: this specific study is a PK/formulation study (healthy volunteers) to alter dosing frequency, so it does not test clinical cognitive efficacy here. citeturn0search1turn0search2

Web search results used: Latrepirdine (Dimebon) summary and development history (Wikipedia). citeturn0search12; PubMed/ACS and systematic review summaries describing pharmacology, proposed neuroprotective/cognition effects and clinical trial failures. citeturn0search3turn0search2.
explanation_agent: Reason: This is a Phase 1 PK/formulation study of an oral small‑molecule (latrepirdine/dimebon) in healthy volunteers; although the study is pharmacokinetic (not an efficacy trial), the drug’s investigational role in Alzheimer’s research was as a cognition‑enhancer with proposed neuroprotective/synaptic effects rather than a single amyloid- or tau‑directed biologic. Latrepirdine has been reported to modulate multiple neurotransmitter systems and mitochondrial/autophagy pathways, consistent with a synaptic‑plasticity/neuroprotection classification. citeturn1search12turn1search4turn1search0

Act: Extracted details — drug: latrepirdine (dimebon), oral small molecule; proposed actions include H1 and various serotonin receptor blockade (e.g., 5‑HT6), modulation of NMDA/AMPA and calcium channels, mitochondrial/mitochondrial pore effects and induction of autophagy; it was developed as a putative cognitive enhancer/neuroprotective agent and advanced to Phase 3 AD trials (which later failed). Given these mechanisms and the cognitive‑enhancer intent, the most appropriate CADRO category is 'M) Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection'. citeturn1search12turn1search2turn1search6

Reflect: The drug is multi‑mechanistic (it also affects neurotransmitter receptors), so one could argue for D) Neurotransmitter Receptors or R) Multi‑target; however, CADRO’s best match for an agent developed to enhance cognition and provide neuroprotection/synaptic support is M) Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection. The current trial’s PK/formulation focus does not change the underlying drug classification. Key supportive literature and reviews are cited below. citeturn1search4turn1search7
- Latrepirdine (Wikipedia) — summary of reported multiple mechanisms (H1, 5‑HT, glutamate modulation, mitochondrial effects). citeturn1search12

- Systematic review of preclinical studies — summarizes diverse proposed targets including mitochondrial, cholinergic/acetylcholinesterase activity, NMDA and calcium modulation; heterogeneous evidence for neuroprotection. citeturn1search4
- Latrepirdine enhances autophagy & reduces intracellular Aβ in model systems (J Alzheimer’s Dis / PubMed). citeturn1search0turn1search5
- Molecular Neurodegeneration paper — latrepirdine alters extracellular Aβ and modulates neurotransmission in vitro/in vivo. citeturn1search2
- Pfizer/Medivation Phase 3 results announcement — clinical development and Phase 3 failure context. citeturn1search6
